title: 7-Eleven scandal: Company announces review of pay practices
text:
The Fair Work Ombudsman has conducted three separate raids on 7-Eleven in the past six years. "While we dispute there is insufficient financial viability in a system that delivers on average net profit of $165,000 per store, and year-on-year growth of more than 9 per cent, the company has committed that any existing franchisee, who no longer wants to participate in the system, 7-Eleven Stores Pty Ltd will refund the franchise fee paid, and help to sell any store where a goodwill payment has been made," 7-Eleven chief executive Warren Wilmot said.
Stores sell for between $400,000 and $1.7 million meaning a mass buyback could cost the company tens of millions of dollars.
A statement from the company released on Monday said it would set up an independent panel which will be chaired by "an eminent and qualified Australian", though the chair was not named by the company in a statement issued on Monday afternoon.
"The key factor here is that the panel will receive, review, and process any claim of underpayment, and authorise repayment where this is appropriate," Mr Wilmot said.
 "The viability of the 7-Eleven system is in no way, never has been and never will be, dependent on franchisees underpaying their staff," he said.
"This doesn't let off the hook any franchisees doing the wrong thing, because we will pursue them to repay any money owed to former or present staff.
Mr Wilmot said the company would cooperate with workplace regulator the Fair Work Commission , which recently launched an investigation into the mass underpayment of 7-Eleven staff, its third such review into the company's practices in the past seven years.
"What has happened, has happened on our watch, and we are a company with a proud heritage and a strong reputation, we cannot allow the few to taint the achievements of the many," Mr Wilmot said.
Meanwhile, the retail employees' union said it would it will win back wages for exploited 7-Eleven workers, launching a dedicated hotline for employees who had been ripped-off.
The Shop Distributive and Allied Employees' Association said on Monday it had been contacted by a number of 7-Eleven employees after a joint Fairfax Media and Four Corners investigation revealed widespread wage abuse at the chain in a series of articles published over the weekend.
"We also suspect underpayment of superannuation and a host of other things that have been going on for 7-Eleven workers simply because they've been unable to put their hand up and tell their employer, 'hey - this isn't right'," SDA national secretary Gerard Dwyer said.
Mr Dwyer said as well as offer advice, the union would help workers take legal action to win back unpaid wages.
"I think we will see a number of back-pay claims that will be made, we will see that there's been exploitation of people in a vulnerable position who've been paid below their award wage," he said.
"We'll be working with them and the relevant authorities to make sure they get their legal entitlements." The SDA's help hotline is 131 732.
The SDA's announcement come as the Fair Work Ombudsman launched legal proceedings against Sydney 7-Eleven franchisee Harmandeep Singh Sarkaria for underpaying two workers at his Blacktown store.
The ombudsman said on Monday that the workers were paid as little as $10 an hour and that one, a Pakistani migrant, was allegedly underpaid $43,633 over two years.
7-Eleven's head office said it supported the ombudsman's action but Mr Dwyer said there were questions about how much the company knew about wage fraud in its stores.
"How could we have such large scale abuse going on inside those chains and the proprietors and the head office not to know that something is wrong?" he said.
Fairfax Media revealed on Monday that 7-Eleven's corporate headquarters had engaged in a massive cover-u p of exploitation in its stores.
Monday's developments came ahead of the evening's broadcast of a major expose on the 7-Eleven scandal on the ABC's Four Corners program.
